title: That Time I Put Beef Fat on My Face (And It Worked)
body:
Okay so. I’m just gonna say it. I’ve been putting beef fat on my face. And my hands. And my elbows. And it’s… weirdly amazing? I know. It sounds like something you’d find in a great-grandma’s diary, not in a skincare routine. But this whipped tallow balm, specifically the bourbon vanilla one, has become this weird little jar of magic on my bathroom shelf. It’s winter, my skin was basically turning into a dried-up riverbed, and nothing from the fancy stores was helping. Then I fell down this whole internet rabbit hole about traditional tallow skincare. You know how it is. One minute you’re looking for a hand cream, the next you’re reading about 19th-century apothecaries. Anyway. That’s how I ended up here, with this jar of whipped beef tallow balm that smells like a cozy kitchen and actually fixes my skin.

It started because my hands were a disaster. Like, cracking, bleeding, painful disaster. I was using this expensive lotion in the fancy bottle. Did nothing. Felt like putting scented water on sandpaper. I was complaining to my friend Sarah and she just goes, “My weird aunt uses tallow. Like, from a cow.” And I made a face. Obviously. Beef fat? For skin? But then I couldn’t stop thinking about it. Later that night, I was half-watching some baking show, my hands stinging, and I just started googling. “Beef tallow history for skin.” Fell right into the hole.

## How I Even Got Here (The Internet Rabbit Hole)

Turns out, putting tallow on your skin isn’t new. It’s, like, ancient. My grandma probably knew about it. Maybe yours did too. People have been using animal fats forever—lard, tallow, bear grease, you name it—to protect and heal skin. It makes sense if you think about it. Before there were labs and chemical emulsifiers, you used what you had. And what they had worked. Tallow from grass-fed cows is packed with vitamins A, D, E, and K, and the fatty acid profile is supposedly really close to our own skin’s sebum. So your skin recognizes it. It’s not some alien chemical compound; it’s like giving your skin something it already understands how to use. The whole “natural skincare comeback” thing isn’t just about plants. Sometimes it’s about going back to what literally nourished people’s skin for centuries. I read that and was like, “Huh.” It stopped sounding gross and started sounding… logical. In a very old-school way. My cat was staring at me from the couch the whole time. Judging.

So I went looking. Found this small shop on Etsy, based in France, that makes this whipped tallow balm. The bourbon vanilla scent sounded the least intimidating. “Warm, comforting, classic,” the description said. I ordered it. I didn’t tell anyone. Felt like a secret weirdo purchase.

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm Actually Does

The jar arrived on a Tuesday, I think. It was cold. The box was simple. I opened it and just stared at the stuff. Texture was… unexpected. Not hard. Not greasy. It’s whipped, so it’s this super light, almost fluffy cream. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it touches your skin. Like, instantly. Doesn’t sit on top. Doesn’t feel slick. It just goes away. Absorbs. That was the first shock. I was braced for grease. Didn’t get it.

The smell. Okay. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. Promise. It smells like… remember those vanilla extract bottles in your mom’s baking cabinet? That pure, warm, almost caramel-like vanilla scent. Not sugary sweet. Not fake. Just warm and cozy. The “bourbon” part just gives it a tiny depth, like a vanilla bean pod, not a cupcake. It’s comforting. Stress-reducing is a good way to put it. Smelling it feels like a deep breath. I put it on my hands first. The cracked patches. It didn’t sting. That was shock number two. My fancy lotion stung. This didn’t. It just… sunk in. My skin felt different. In a good way. Not coated. Just quieter. Less angry.

I got braver after a few days. Used it on my face. I have this dry, flaky patch on my cheek that shows up every winter. I’ve thrown so much money at it. I put a little of the tallow balm on it at night. Woke up. It was still there, but softer. Less red. After three nights? Gone. Just normal skin. I didn’t know what to do with myself. I just stood in the bathroom light poking my cheek. Weird.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Weirdness

So it’s been maybe a month now. Maybe six weeks. I’ve lost track. The jar is about half gone. I use it every night. Sometimes in the morning if it’s really cold. My winter skin damage routine is basically just this now. My hands don’t crack anymore. My elbows, which were always rough and lizard-y, are smooth. I don’t even know when they were last smooth. High school? It’s that kind of result. It’s not a temporary fix. It’s like the tallow balm helps my skin remember how to be skin. I read that’s because of the sebum-mimicking thing. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks to repair itself, not just slapping a bandage on top.

I told my mom about it. She was skeptical. Then her psoriasis on her elbows flared up bad. She tried everything. I finally just sent her a jar. She called me last week. “What is in this stuff?” she said. “It’s the only thing that’s calmed it down.” She’s a believer now too. We’re a beef tallow family, I guess. Who knew.

The best part is the simplicity. My skincare shelf used to have ten bottles. Serums, toners, creams, oils. Now I have like, three things. And this tallow balm is the heavy lifter. It’s multitasking. Face, hands, cuticles, dry patches. It’s the one thing that actually works. I’m on my second jar already. Got it from the same little Etsy shop. It feels good to buy from someone making small batches, you know? Not some giant corporation.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did.

Look, I’m not a skincare expert. I’m just someone whose skin was miserable and found something that made it not miserable. The whole “beef tallow history” thing is cool and gives me context, but at the end of the day, I just care that it works. And this does. It’s not magic. It’s just… really good, simple nourishment. My skin feels stronger. Healthier. It doesn’t freak out when the wind blows anymore.

If you’re curious about this whole traditional tallow skincare revival, I’d say just try it. Start with your hands. See what you think. It’s one of those things you have to feel to get. Reading about it sounds strange. Using it feels… normal. And right.

Anyway. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it can be. Especially if it’s from grass-fed cows and processed cleanly. The idea is that it’s similar to the oils our skin makes naturally, so it absorbs deep and helps repair the barrier. It worked on my dry, flaky face patches when nothing else did.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores. Because it’s so similar to our sebum, it seems to absorb fully instead of sitting on top of the skin. It’s non-comedogenic. But everyone’s skin is different, so maybe patch test first.

**What does the bourbon vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
Just pure, warm vanilla. Like real vanilla beans or good extract. Not candy-sweet. It’s cozy and subtle. The bourbon part just makes it a little deeper, less sweet. It doesn’t smell like food or dessert, just… nice. Comforting. The smell fades pretty quickly after you put it on, too.
